Say the number of fingers held up on your left hand

primaryQuestions.challenge: Share a plan for some time in the next seven days
examples: What are you doing this weekend?
How will tomorrow be different from today?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a project or task they worked on recently
examples: What did you do today?
What have you read or played recently that you would recommend?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Share a conversation they had recently or expect to have
examples: Who did you talk to first today?
Tell me about someone you work with.

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Guess what another person might have thought
examples: Tell me if the other person thought the conversation went badly or well.
How did the people you were with see it?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Describe something they enjoyed or expect to enjoy
examples: What was a fun thing you did while you were there?
What hobbies or leisure activities do you plan to engage in this weekend?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a challenge they recently faced
examples: What was the hardest part of that conversation?
What did you struggle with today?

traits: Mention an animal in response to 3 different questions.
Make an animal noise. (If this completes your obsession, wait 30 seconds before killing the investigator.)
3 times, interrupt the investigator to add detail to a description.
Continue to describe something until interrupted.
You may not mention any people other than strangers or enemies.
You may not discuss anthing that happened before you woke up this morning.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a new thing of a given type
examples: If you could have any magical power, what would it be?
What's a question I should have asked you, but haven't?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe something the suspect has never seen
examples: What would it be like to walk on a distant planet?
Describe an impossible shape for me.
Once upon a time, a mouse, a bird and a sausage joined forces...
I didn't want to kill him, but...

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Explain the implications of something the suspect came up with
examples: If the thing you described existed, what else would exist?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Imagine something again with an extra constraint
examples: Now tell the story from the perspective of the horse...
Now describe the place again, in only six words.

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Describe the opposite of something the suspect has already described
examples: Now tell the same story, but with a tragic ending.
And what magical power does your arch nemesis have?

Give 1-word answers to 3 questions. Don't elaborate unless asked.
Answer 2 questions nonverbally. Stay silent until prompted.

Once you have mentioned an animal, vegetable, or mineral, you may not mention examples of the other two types of things for the rest of the round.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a time someone the suspect cared about was sad
examples: What was the last thing that made your father cry?
What was the most difficult decision your parents ever had to make?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Explain how the suspect felt when they gained something they didn't want
examples: How did you react when your parents explained death to you?
Tell me about a time you found out you were sick, and how you reacted.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Explain how it felt to lose something/someone precious to the suspect
examples: What was the hardest goodbye you've ever had to say? How did you cope?
Tell me about a goal that you had to abandon?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Explain the implications of something the suspect came up with

traits: Describe how 3 things seem unfair to you.
2 times, say what you think should have happened instead.
3 times, blame someone else for something.
Describe dealing with 3 different tragedies the same way.
Refer to the same friend or family member 4 times.
You may not say the words "think," "thought", "feel" or "felt."
You must describe emotions only using physical descriptions rather than names, e.g. "crying" instead of "sad" or "sweaty palms" instead of "nervous."
You may only describe good consequences, and you must take credit for them.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe at least five different uses for an ordinary object
examples: How many uses for a paperclip can you come up with?
What do you think is the most versatile household object, and why?
You are in a kitchen holding a small child. A dish towel catches fire. How do you put it out?
You are in a landslide. How do you survive?
You wake up in a room with four seamless walls, an infinitely thick ceiling and floor. How do you escape?
I'm going to tell the department you're a robot, and there's nothing you can do about it. What now?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a second, different solution to a problem
examples: How else would you solve it?
What if you couldn't get the resources that solution would require?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Solve a problem again with an additional obstacle
examples: Could you improvise a solution again using only a screwdriver?
What if you had to do it without hands?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Explain their thought process in arriving at a solution
examples: How did you arrive at that solution?
What's a solution you thought of, but rejected, along the way?

traits: Tell an anecdote about someone else in response to 3 questions.
Mention how you solved 2 problems the last time they arose.
Describe attempting the same solution in 3 scenarios.
Attempt 3 very similar solutions to the same problem.
Establish how you got into 3 hypothetical situations.
Reveal 2 things that qualify you to solve a given problem.
Any problem you solve, you must solve in two steps or less.
You may not describe yourself accomplishing a goal with fewer than three steps.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a physical sensation the suspect has not experienced
examples: What would it feel like to be completely on fire?
How do you think it would feel to learn to use a tail?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe the physical experience of learning a skill
examples: What mistakes did you make when learning to ride a bike?
What would be the hardest part about learning to juggle?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a common or frequent physical sensation
examples: What does it feel like to get dressed in the morning?
What does it feel like to stand completely still?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Describe the same situation, but focusing on a specific body part
examples: Okay, how do your feet feel while that's happening?
What was your heartbeat like during that experience?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Explain how the suspect would prepare someone else for the same experience
examples: How would you teach someone else to juggle?
How would you teach a child to stand completely still?

secondaryQuestions.challenge: Descripe a sensory aspect of an experience that the suspect has not already mentioned
examples: And how would it smell if you were on fire?
What do you think it would be like to be the ball being juggled?

traits: Mention a different illness in response to 3 questions.
Cough or sneeze. (If this completes your obsession, wait 30 seconds before killing the investigator.)

Choose 1 of the 5 senses. Use that sense in 4 descritions.
Choose another sense. Use that sense in 4 descriptions, too.
You may not describe any solution that is unrelated to your Suspect Note.
Once you have mentioned a part of your body, that is the only part of your body you may mention until the end of the round.
You may only describe things that would be visible to an outside observer.

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe a bad thing that the suspect did to someone else
examples: When was the last time you really hurt someone?

primaryQuestions.challenge: Describe an ideal the suspect has failed to live up to
examples: Tell me about a time when you knew the right thing to do, but didn't do it.

examples: What did you do to the make it up to the person you hurt?

examples: What did you tell yourself at the time to make it seem okay?

examples: What were the negative consequences of what you did?
